results.title: The Witches of Eastwick
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Peter Guber, Neil Canton, Guber-Peters Company and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In a sleepy new England town, three women- Alex, Jane and Sukie (Cher, Susan Sarandon, Michelle Pfeiffer) gather each Thursday to drink, lament the lack of eligible bachelors in their neighbourhood, and fanstasize about their dream partner. Enter wealthy and attractive Daryl van Horne (Jack Nicholson) whom they have innocently conjured up; unbeknownst to them he is the devil in disguise. It’s not long before Daryl has slept with Alex, Jane and Sukie and the town gossip starts- spear headed by local busy body Felicia Alden (Veronica Cartwright), who soon has a nasty experience with some cherries. The women begin to suspect they are not dealing with no ordinary man and must combine their reinvigorated female energy to defeat Satan himself in the ultimate battle of the sexes. Based on the book by John Updike.

results.title: The Watermelon Woman
results.creator_credit: Cheryl Dunye, Alexandra Juhasz, Barry Swimar and Dancing Girl Productions
results.brief_description: One of the first feature films made by an African American lesbian, this ‘mockumentary’ ostensibly investigates the life of a forgotten black actress from the thirties known only as, the Watermelon Woman. Filmmaker Cheryl Dunye plays herself as a video shop employee and budding film director who begins researching the actress with a view to making a movie based upon her life story. As she uncovers archival footage and conducts interviews with archivists, scholars (played in a series of cameos by real-life experts including Camille Paglia) and women who lived in the Philadelphia area in the thirties, Dunye pieces together a previously unacknowledged history of African American lesbian life in the thirties. She finds that the Watermelon Woman was a nightclub singer named Fae Richards who was the lover of the white Hollywood female director, Martha Page. Meanwhile, Dunye herself falls in love with Diana (Guinevere Turner), one of the customers that frequent the video store where she works. Their passionate relationship allows her to explore her own feelings around interracial romance. The film functions on two levels, as a wry, irreverent look at contemporary black lesbian culture, and as a critique of official narratives that have erased this culture from history. While Dunye ultimately reveals the Watermelon Woman as a fiction, she points out that “sometimes you have to create you own history”.

constellations_other.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

results.title: The Waterboy
results.creator_credit: Frank Coraci, Jack Giarraputo, Robert Simonds and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: In this comedic film of sight gags Adam Sandler plays the role of Bobby Boucher, a water boy for the local college football team. Bobby cops it from all directions - his over-bearing mother (Kathy Bates), the football team and even the coach (Jerry Reed). When the coach fires him, Bobby is forced to join the rival team under Coach Klein (Henry Winkler) where he turns his talents from water boy to a star tackler setting this losing team on the road to victory. Love, glory and revenge await Bobby as he takes up his new life as a football hero and college student. Cast includes Fairuza Balk, Blake Clark and Larry Gilliard Jr.

results.title: The Violinist
results.brief_description: An animated spoof of the old saying - to create great music the artist must suffer. Harry, the street violinist, makes music which dismays even his own dog. He tries everything, including music lessons but his music does not improve until he takes advice and begins to suffer.

results.title: The Vikings
results.creator_credit: Richard Fleischer, Jerry Bresler and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Set in an era rife with bloody raids, gory sword battles and brutal acts of violence, this is the saga of the loves and lusts of the fierce Norse raiders who swept over Europe bringing death and destruction over a thousand years ago. Leading an all-star cast is Kirk Douglas as Einar, hot-blooded, hedonistic son of the Viking chieftain Ragnar (Ernest Borgnine). Years before, Ragnar had molested the British Queen Enid, murdered her husband and left her with child. Enid had secretly sent the baby away to protect the rightful heir from the Viking invaders. Twenty years later, the child grows up to become the proud slave, Eric (Tony Curtis), whose true identity - and love for the Welsh princess Morgana (Janet Leigh) - forces him into an inevitable, climactic showdown with his vicious half-brother, Einar. The authentically staged raids and magnificently filmed panoramas of the Norwegian Fjords and the rugged French coast make this a spectacular and thrilling adventure tale.

results.title: The Unsinkable Molly Brown
results.creator_credit: Helen Deutsch, Lawrence Weingarten and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Debbie Reynolds stars in her Oscar nominated performance as the eponymous Molly Brown. Destined for better things, Western orphan Molly leaves her mountain cabin and her uneducated and poor upbringing in search of a rich husband and a better life in Denver society. In a typical rags to riches fashion, Molly becomes the wealthiest woman in society. Based on the musical play with music and lyrics by Meredith Wilson. Screen play by Helen Deutsch. Cast includes Debbie Reynolds, Harve Presnell and Ed Begley.

results.title: The Underneath
results.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, John Hardy and Populist Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Chambers (Peter Gallagher) is a gambling addict who returns to his Texas home town to celebrate his mother’s re-marriage. The past is quick to catch up with him in the shape of his jealous brother and Rachel (Alison Elliott), a former girlfriend now married to the local ‘big man’, Tommy. Michael and Rachel rekindle their affair and soon plot to elope with the proceeds from a bank robbery. For the plan to succeed, Michael needs to involve his father-in-law to be and Susan, the bank manager who happens to be a former fling. Marking Soderbergh’s re-emergence following the early success of ‘Sex, lies and videotape’, ‘The Underneath’ combines the classic elements of film noir with an added spin on the deceptive nature of modern relationships. Filmmaker Richard Linklater and Shelley Duvall appear briefly in this film. ‘The Underneath’ is based on the novel ‘Criss Cross’ by Don Tracy. It is a faithful re-make of the film ‘Criss Cross’ directed by Robert Sidomak and starring Burt Lancaster (1948). This video is a modified version of the originally filmed in Cinemascope film.

results.title: The Tenant of Wildfell Hall
results.creator_credit: Suzan Harrison, BBC, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, WGBH (Boston) and Mike Barker
results.brief_description: Anne Bronte’s novel of an unhappy marriage deals with the themes of self-sacrifice, adulterous passion and redemption set amongst the rugged but beautiful landscape of the Yorkshire Dales. Helen Graham, a widow with a young son, is the new tenant of Wildfell Hall. Her radical views and her aloofness attracts the local young squire Gilbert Markham but despite the attraction, Helen has a secret which prevents their love from blossoming. Starring Tara Fitzgerald, Toby Stephens and Rupert Graves.

results.title: The Tenant
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski, Andrew Braunsberg and Marianne Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Richard Topor, “The Tenant” is a psychological horror film by Roman Polanski which can also be read as a deeply disturbed personal work about a man’s disintegration in the face of death and tragedy. (There are obvious parallels to be drawn by the mental disintegration of the film’s main character, Trelkovsky - played by Polanski himself - to the crisis suffered by the director when his wife and unborn child were brutally slaughtered by the infamous Charles Manson cult). Polanski’s work from the beginning of his career has seen him play mischievously and surrealistically with the themes of mental illness, hauntings and transvestitism, but in “The Tenant”, the whole world which Trelkovsky inhabits seems to be riddled with varying degrees of evil and repressed violence. He is a new tenant in an old Baroque Parisian hotel and the last occupant in his room attempted suicide by jumping from the building. Trelkovsky meets her on the day of her death: the memory of her anguished screaming will reverberate with him for the rest of his life. The cast includes Isabelle Adjani, Melvyn Douglas, Shelley Winters and Lila Kedrova, and the sombre lighting and cinematography is by noted Swedish cinematographer, Sven Nykvist. As always, Polanski proves an effective and imaginative master of the horror genre. Note: “The Tenant” is a USA/French co-production in which the French actors are dubbed into English.
